good afternoon so I guess there's a really simple message that I want to
communicate and that is that I think Australian country companies are under

let's talk a little bit about a previous era of disruption if we go back a

Australia our national champions or iconic brands became successful companies and every company of course

today problems are being solved globally
not locally and increasingly they're being solved by software-driven businesses now not every
problem is being solved globally not every problem is being solved by software driven business models but a
huge proportion of the biggest problems today are being solved globally not
locally and by software driven business models and those two factors are very much related if you think about these
software driven business models there's two things about them that really really stand out one is they have an enormous

era is distribution costs are zero you combine those two things together it
means that global will be local in many cases and so for example we listen to
music on Spotify there are isn't an Australian streaming service that we
listen to we book accommodation we booked a holiday on air B&B AWS provides
us with our cloud services and of course we've produced a good number of our own
local champions but we need to produce a lot lot more and the reality is is for
our companies that have become the best in Australia at what they do they are at
risk of being disrupted unless they become the best in the world of what they do and we're going to see that in
market after market and so our economy which is built on national champions is
more at risk of disruption than many other economies I said we don't spend a
lot on our and D in that spenders declining but if you accept the proposition that many of the problems in

because if you isolate Australia's R&D our business R&D spend focus on ICT as a

or seven percent of what they spend in Israel on ICT R&D we're about eighty
five ninety percent less than what spent in the u.s. we're a la garde in terms of expenditure or R&D in ICT industries and
so we've got a range of factors that mean that we are very very vulnerable in
an era of technology disruption the low level of R&D spend the fact that many of
our most successful companies are national leaders in a world increasingly of global rather than local winners the

Australian businesses from boards of Australian companies that investors in Australia are increasingly focused on
profitability rather than long-term growth and investing in that growth the
number of times I've heard from non-executive directors or senior executives of Australian companies

boards many of our CIOs and CTOs don't really have a
at the table in a lot of cases they're reporting to CFO's or other people in the organization rather than sitting to

challenges for us but of course we've got some amazing exceptions we have

we are now spending more we're now investing more in venture capital than

markets so there are some positive signs but the overall message the overall
message that I want to leave people in the room with is today we have a
slow-burning platform it is a burning platform that is masked by 28 years of
consecutive economic growth it is completely understandable in that context that we are complacent but we
have a burning platform and most particularly our companies that are
dominant players in the Australian economy are the ones that are most vulnerable we have the raw ingredients
